DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu Says Iraq Should Withdraw from Iranian Territory
Eds: RECASTS grafs 1-2; picks up 3d `Iran's official'
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nicolae Ceausescu of Romania, visiting Iran while his security forces suppress protesters at home, laid a wreath Tuesday at the tomb of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and spoke of peace in the Persian Gulf. The Romanian president said Iraqis should withdraw from Iranian territory so the rival neighbors can sign a peace treaty. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted Ceausescu as saying an Iraqi withdrawal ``is the starting point for implementation of U.N. Security Council Resolution 598, and we are trying our best in the Security Council to enforce this resolution.'' While Ceausescu was in Tehran, reports from Romania indicated security forces may have killed hundreds of people during weekend demonstrations against Ceausescu, who runs the last Stalinist regime in the Soviet bloc. Romania has virtually sealed its borders and official media have not reported the unrest. A U.N.-mediated truce ended an 8-year-old war between Iran and Iraq in August 1988, but peace talks have not resolved their differences. Iran insists the Iraqis withdraw from territory occupied in the last weeks of the war. Iraq wants a border that gives it full control of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, its sole outlet to the Persian Gulf. Tehran radio said Ceausescu met separately with Vice President Roghani Zanjani and Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati on Tuesday, the second day of a three-day official visit. He and Zanjani discussed an agreement under which Iran will export about 1 billion cubic meters of natural gas and 1 million barrels of oil a year to Romania. Romania is Iran's second-largest trading partner in Eastern Europe. The estimated volume this year is about $1.8 billion. According to the radio, Ceausescu expressed readiness to cooperate with Iran in ``numerous'' fields, stressing cooperation in mining. Earlier Tuesday, Ceausescu laid a wreath at Khomeini's tomb in the Beheshte Zahra cemetery outside Tehran. The revolutionary patriarch died June 3. In a reference to Ceausescu's resistance to pro-democracy reforms sweeping the Soviet bloc, Iran's official news agency praised Romania on Monday as ``the sole east European country rigidly adhering to its past government.'' Ceausescu became Communist Party chief March 22, 1965, and now is the longest-serving leader in Eastern Europe.
